cern_snow_client package¶

The CERN ServiceNow Client library (CERN SNow Client) facilitates the usage of the ServiceNow REST API with a CERN account via Single Sign On authentication. Basic Authentication is also supported.

Low level operations such as get, post and put are implemented. Also, other higher level operations have been implemented, such as querying/inserting/updating records, or querying/inserting/updating incidents and requests, including adding comments and work notes.

cern_snow_client.session module¶

class cern_snow_client.session.SnowRestSession[source]¶

Bases: object

This class behaves very similarly to a requests.Session object. It can be configured by loading a .yaml config file, or by setting attributes.

Load a .yaml configuration file

Parameters:

config_file_path (str) – the path to the configuration file
Raises:
  • SnowRestSessionException – if no file is found at the specified path, or some inconsistency is found in the file.
  • Exception – if some other error happens when opening or parsing the file

get(url, headers=None, params=None)[source]¶

Executes a raw GET operation and returns the result. Used to read or retrieve information. The authentication method, and session cookie / OAuth tokens persistance will depend on how the session has been configured.

Parameters:
  • url (str) – an absolute URL
  • headers (dict, optional) – any additional headers to be be passed. If not set, the ‘Accept’ header will be set to ‘application/json’
  • params (dict, optional) – any additional URL parameters to be be passed
Returns:

If the status code is not 401, a requests.Response object is returned. The structure of the result inside the ‘text’ attribute might vary depending on the REST endpoint called and the way that the query is configured. ServiceNow may also set various HTTP status codes or headers in the response.
Return type:

requests.Response
Raises:

SnowRestSessionException – if the operation could not be performed due to an authentication issue
post(url, headers=None, params=None, data=None)[source]¶

Executes a raw POST operation and returns the result. Used to insert records or other information. The authentication method, and session cookie / OAuth tokens persistance will depend on how the session has been configured.

Parameters:
  • url (str) – an absolute URL
  • headers (dict, optional) – any additional headers to be be passed. If not set, the ‘Accept’ header will be set to ‘application/json’, and ‘Content’ will be set to ‘application/json’
  • params (dict, optional) – any additional URL parameters to be be passed
  • data (object) – the data that will be submitted via POST. For example, a dictionary of keys and values.
Returns:

If the status code is not 401, a requests.Response object is returned. The structure of the result inside the ‘text’ attribute might vary depending on the REST endpoint called, but typically represents the record resulting from the insert. ServiceNow may also set various HTTP status codes or headers in the response.
Return type:

requests.Response
Raises:

SnowRestSessionException – if the operation could not be performed due to an authentication issue
put(url, headers=None, params=None, data=None)[source]¶

Executes a raw PUT operation and returns the result. Used to update records or other information. The authentication method, and session cookie / OAuth tokens persistance will depend on how the session has been configured.

Parameters:
  • url (str) – an absolute URL
  • headers (dict, optional) – any additional headers to be be passed. If not set, the ‘Accept’ header will be set to ‘application/json’, and ‘Content’ will be set to ‘application/json’
  • params (dict, optional) – any additional URL parameters to be be passed
  • data (object) – the data that will be submitted via PUT. For example, a dictionary of keys and values.
Returns:

If the status code is not 401, a requests.Response object is returned. The structure of the result inside the ‘text’ attribute might vary depending on the REST endpoint called, but typically represents the state of the record after the update. ServiceNow may also set various HTTP status codes or headers in the response.
Return type:

requests.Response
Raises:

SnowRestSessionException – if the operation could not be performed due to an authentication issue
get_record(table, sys_id=None, number=None, headers=None, params=None)[source]¶

Executes a GET operation in order to read a single record from a ServiceNow table. The authentication method, and session cookie / OAuth tokens persistance will depend on how the session has been configured.

Parameters:
  • table (str) – the name of a ServiceNow table, such as incident. Mandatory parameter.
  • sys_id (str) – the sys_id (ServiceNow unique identifier) of the record to be read. Giving either a sys_id or a number parameter is mandatory, but not both.
  • number (str) – the number of the record to be read. Can be used if the table has a Number field. Giving either a sys_id or a number parameter is mandatory, but not both.
  • headers (dict, optional) – any additional headers to be be passed. If not set, the ‘Accept’ header will be set to ‘application/json’.
  • params (dict, optional) – any additional URL parameters to be be passed. For a complete list, please see: https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/helsinki-application-development/page/integrate/inbound-rest/concept/c_TableAPI.html#ariaid-title3
Returns:

If the status code is not 401, a requests.Response object is returned.

The ‘text’ will contain a JSON or XML representation of the record. The response will also contain headers. For a list of headers, please see: https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/helsinki-application-development/page/integrate/inbound-rest/concept/c_TableAPI.html#d45069e608
Return type:

requests.Response
Raises:

SnowRestSessionException – if mandatory parameters are missing, or if the operation could not be performed due to an authentication issue
